Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 06:22PM hansaim wrote: I had radiation to my pelvis and spine shortly after stage 4 dx and my TM 15-3 was up.  My onc told me that radiation did not affect the TM but systematic therapies (hormonal or chemo) did.  For me, it turned out that Aromasin was not working and cancer was spreading during that time.  Since I started Xeloda, TM has been going down.
Posts.Title: Tumor Marker CA-15-3 question related to bone mets / radiation Survivortimes2 stagefree

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 09:20AM hansaim wrote: Hello, I am so sorry to hear about your dx.  I cried everyday for the first few months.  I do not have liver mets, but dx'ed with bone mets last July at age 42.  Like you, I was on tamoxifen when bone mets were found.  I have two children (10 and 8).  There are many ladies here with liver mets who are doing very well.  I hope they will chime in soon.  I know two ladies in my mets support group who have breast cancer liver mets; one going on 10 years and the other 8.5.  There are many treatment options.  Once you start the treatment, you will feel better, though it may take time.  Hugs.
Posts.Title: Seriously?? Just re-diagnosed Stage IV with two liver mets..... wildrumara nbnotes

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2017 10:47AM hansaim wrote: I had 6 cycles of Abraxane last year. Xeloda failed and lung mets appeared last spring and my MO suggested Abraxane. Fatigue and hair loss were the worst for me. The infusion time was only 30 min and no pre-meds, so quick in and out for treatments. Hair started coming out after the 2nd cycle so I shaved it all off. It did wonders for the lung mets; some shrunk and some disappeared. I wish you the best outcome.
Posts.Title: Abraxane Kandy illimae

Posts.Content: May 13, 2015 12:48PM hansaim wrote: Garlikbread, I hear you. I have two elementary school kids. I feed sad and angry when I see other families living their lives while I try to act normal. It is so tiring. At the same time, I was very grateful last Sunday that I was here for my kids for another Mother's day. They made gifts in the class. I imagined that my kids might be the only ones in the class having to make Mother's day gifts without a mom. How heart breaking. I hope you get some help from your medical team to help you feel better. Hugs.

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 07:09PM hansaim wrote: I had 1 trip since my stage 4 dx.  I was afraid of leaving home.  My palliative doctor gave me a 24/7 phone number where I could get a hold of her team of doctors.  In addition, I bought something called, medical evacuation plan.  This is different from the travel insurance in that in case of hospitalization, it would provide medical air transport to my home hospital.  It was peace of mind for me.

I started with Aromasin and had radiation on the pelvis and spine. Within two months, the pain became worse and I was so unstable on my feet that I had to get a walker to get around in the house. I called my MO and ended up changing the treatment. When was your last scan and next appointment with your MO? I would not wait until the next scheduled appointment.

Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2017 08:18PM hansaim wrote: Hello, I want to introduce myself here. I was dx'ed with bone mets in 2013, lung mets in 2015 then liver mets in 2016. With treatments, I have been doing well, while dealing with bone pain, limping and fatigue, and of course progression. I was on Halaven since Aug 2016, which stopped working early Dec. Hormonal treatments alone did not work for me at all. Now I have shortness of breath and coughing, which I am finding very scary. Any more than a few steps get me out of breath!! Driving my kids after school has been my steady job but I am finding it hard to get to the garage now. I am scared that I may be starting the down hill while praying that this is another bump. I started Faslodex and Ibrance last week. The chest x-ray showed small amount of fluid on the left. I am seeing my MO and palliative doctor next week, but in the mean time I wanted to check in with the wise ladies here and ask how you are managing shortness of breath.
Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2017 12:24PM hansaim wrote: The mets in the lungs are making it difficult for oxygen to get through. I wish I were on an IV chemo as it would work faster, I think. I had Abraxane (very similar to Taxol) last year, and it did wonders to my lung mets. All the best, Sadie.
Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

Posts.Content: May 29, 2015 03:53PM hansaim wrote: Great advises above. Before I was first dx'ed with stage 2, I did not know anything about cancer other than people died from it. So when I was dx'ed with stage 4, I only told my husband and immediate family. I also told my close friends at work as I stopped working. I held it from my children (8 and 10 yrs old at the time) for a few months. It gave me time to deal with it myself and figure out how and whom to tell. When I told my kids, I also told the teachers, their friends' families and my close friends that the cancer came back and that I would need treatment but I did not elaborate that it was stage 4. After 2 years, I still tell when asked that I am in treatment and it will continue as long as I need it. I wish you speedy return of NED. Hugs.
Posts.Title: Telling (or not telling) friends and family ABeautifulSunset steelrose

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2017 04:09PM hansaim wrote: Sadie, 6 cycles of Taxol seem reasonable. Hope that you would feel the difference after each cycle. With my last chemo, I started to feel better after 2 cycles. I am out of breath; on home oxygen and on a wheel chair at the moment. Just a few steps get me panting. I have never had this until 3 weeks ago, it's very new and scary and all. It just happened so quickly. Doctors do not seem to worry about built up fluid in my case. Thank you for being here, everyone.
Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

I am already mildly anaemic and have been on iron for a while. Today's lab showed low WBC which is not unusual for me. But also high Gamma GT. I am worried that it might indicate liver mets, yikes...Hope everyone is well.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2016 07:49PM hansaim wrote: GG, you are full of good news. Glad to hear that hips are getting better. Will make a big difference in balance and mobility. I had extensive mets in pelvis but much better now. Hope that Arimidex keeps you stable for a long time. Jennifer, keep us posted with your scan. It would good to be off of chemo for a while. I do not do well with hormonals though the pathology showed ER+, PR+. I did not know each cycle of Halavenis two treatments. I am feeling fine today. No nausea, yet. Will see how it goes in the next couple of days. The hospital scheduled me for 6 cycles. I just hope that it works well and my body can take it as planned. A beautiful sunny day here in BC! Will go out and soak in some sun.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2016 05:39PM hansaim wrote: Hi, Rseman. Hair started coming out after the second treatment for me. When I combed, there was a bunch off. I found the worst was during the shower as lots of hair came off and I noticed that the hair line actually changed! I had to lint roll my shoulders several times a day. This continued during the 2nd cycle. By the 3rd cycle, I did not have much to lose, so cleaning up became easier. The infusion itself is pretty easy. Once you have the IV going, the injection takes about 5 min. Sending you a big hug today.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 07:14PM hansaim wrote: I take melatonin every night.  I have many excuses for staying in all day like pain, fatigue, bad weather, but I find that walking around the block during the day helps me at night.  Lack of sleep is such a pain.  Hope you find something that helps you soon.
Posts.Title: Sleep issues Kjones13 Kjones13

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2016 03:14AM hansaim wrote: Hello, I just wanted to introduce myself. I got a call today that I would start Halaven in Aug. I was dx'ed 3 years ago and have had xeloda, Abraxane, faslodex/Afinitor. The nurse went over all the side effects with me today. I am off to Banff with my family for 2 weeks then a new chemo. My ca15-3 has been creeping up so I knew change of treatment was coming. Hope that Halaven is kind to everyone here
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2016 02:25AM hansaim wrote: Jennifer, that is fab news. Not sure what CMF is. Is it an oral chemo or IV? I hope that it would keep you stable for a long time. This has been a slow thread. I am finding Halaven very doable; no nausea, fatigue on day 2 and 3. My white counts are taking a beating but I get Neupogen/Neulasta. I started the 3rd cycle yesterday. I have enough hair on the sides and the back of my head so I wear a cap everywhere. TM 15-3 has been dropping, from 240 to 110, so far. The plan is to scan after 4 cycles and stop after 6 or 7 cycles.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2016 04:24AM hansaim wrote: Hello, all. I finished the 4th cycle today. The CA 15-3 has dropped from 200 to 53, so it seems to be working. I find Halaven easier than Abraxane I had last year. I get the infusion on Friday and I feel the worst on Sunday with fatigue. I have neuropathy on my finger tips and feet and some nausea. My white counts always take a beating so I get neupogen after every treatment. HAIR-- I did lose my hair, unfortunately. The last two times, I shaved as soon as hair started coming out. This time, as I was hoping that hair would just thin out, I did not shave. I still have some hair left on the sides and back that a hat does the trick. In the first couple of weeks, it was messy as I was shedding everywhere. I vacuumed my head and shoulders and used the lint roller. Hate losing hair! It's the touque season, so it's not as bad as in the summer. I have not worked since my dx 3 years ago. I am amazed at the gals who continue to work while coping with stage 4. All the best. Wishing that Halaven does wonders for all of us.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2016 08:51PM hansaim wrote: I guess the question is how much thinning. I had hoped that I would be able to go out without a hat for a while, but by the 2nd cycle, the look was just wrong, people who do not know about my illness would have asked what's up. I am not completely bald, yet. Maybe that's what the doctors mean that we won't be completely bald. Hope you sail through the treatment.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 03:53PM hansaim wrote: Hi, Tasha.  I have mets in pelvis and spine, T11.  I had radiation for pain control; 5 pelvis sessions and 1 spine.  A day or two after the radiation, the pain was worse, but about 2 weeks after the treatment, I noticed improvement.  I did not have any skin problems this time.  But pelvis radiation gave me loose stools for a week.  After the spine radiation, I had nausea.  Also fatigue.  My last session was just over 2 weeks ago, I am still exhausted.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Rads for bc bone mets? any advice welcome tasha_111 BethCon1

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2015 03:18AM hansaim wrote: Timely post. I just switched my care to another MO. I have been with my MO since stage 2 dx in 2011 and went back to her in 2013 with mets. She is one of the breast specialists at a large research hospital. I chose to be referred there thinking that I would have the benefit of being cared by a doctor who is on top of the latest research and clinical trials, etc. However, my treatment so far has been pretty standard; tamoxifen failure right away to mets, A/A (with Afinitor only for a month) failed, then Xeloda for 16 months, onto to 6 cycles of Abraxane. She gave me 2 months of chemo break in Aug. When I asked that I wanted to try another hormonal like Faslodex, she did not think that I would benefit. and said no. After the break, the CT showed some progression in lungs and lymph nodes. She said to continue the break for another 2 months until the end of December. YIKES!! I am 45 and relatively in good health to handle treatments right now. I sought a second opinion and started Faslodex with Afinitor this week. Praying hard that the combo can keep me going for a while. But if it does not, I can cross off the combo off the chart and move on.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2015 01:03AM hansaim wrote: Chris, sorry to hear that you are going thru a rough spell. After my bone mets diagnosis, I was put on Afinitor/Aromasin combo. After a couple of months, I could not walk due to pain and unstability. My dad wheeled me to my appointments and I needed a walker in the house. Switched to Xeloda and I went to using a cane within 2 months. I pray that Halaven does wonders for you. It is great that pain is getting better already. Hugs.
Posts.Title: Checking in again ... :) reader123 RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2015 10:07PM hansaim wrote: I have bone mets. When the pain was bad, I was on long lasting hydromorphone 5 mg and for break through pain, 1 mg pills. My pain improved significantly after radiation and Xeloda. Now I take OTC Tylenol or Ibuprofen when I need. There are many pain medicine options. You may want to consult with pain management specialist. At my hospital, there is a team of doctors and nurses who help with pain and symptom management. I hope that you get the pain under control quickly. It made all the difference in my life when the pain became tolerable. Hugs.

I've been taking X for over a year now and my TM has stayed low. Hang in there. Hope X is killing the bad stuff.

Posts.Content: hansaim wrote: Hello, everyone.  I know there is another thread on radiation but it has 190 posts, so posting a new question. I was dx'ed with bone mets in pelvis and femur 3 weeks ago.  I met with the radiation onc. on Wed.  She told me that I would get one treatment.  Just wanted to know if it is common to do only one session.  The other tread mentions many sessions like 10, 20, for weeks, etc.  Has anyone done just one?  Dx 3/2011, IDC, 3cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 1/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 7/14/2013, Stage IV Hormonal Therapy 1/8/2017 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 1/9/2017 Ibrance (palbociclib) Hormonal Therapy Faslodex (fulvestrant) Chemotherapy Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy Halaven (eribulin) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How many radiation sessions for bone mets? hansaim hansaim

Posts.Content: hansaim wrote: Yes, I am.  It was a year ago that I was told by an ER doctor that my hip pain was due to breast cancer mets.  5 days after the diagnosis, my family went on the planned camping trip to Oregon coast.  DH and I were in shock and cried when the kids were not looking.  I was in pain and could not do much of anything but limping around when not crying.   3 months of A/A combo which failed, then 9 months of Xeloda. We just got back from 2 weeks of camping on the Oregon coast today.  We went to two of the same parks that we went last year.  I was able to bike with the kids, flew kites on the beach, checked out museums, etc. It was beautiful.  I was able to enjoy the time with my family and make memories for my kids.  I am so thankful. The littlest and simplest everyday things just triggered tears; like hugging my little boy who's 8 yrs, watching another family doing something together, it was endless. Now I am a few months in. I still have bad days now and again. It is normal. Cry and yell if you need. Come here and read encouraging posts. Take care.
Posts.Title: I'm crying all the time Roxie43 Kjones13

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2013 11:00PM hansaim wrote: Yes, I did ask the radiation oncologist why only one treatment.  The response was that there was a study of 1 treatment vs. 5 and 70% of the time, a single treatment was sufficient to relieve pain.  She said that the pain may worsen before getting better.  I am to contact her in 1 month time if pain persists.  I am in Canada (public health care system) and I am thinking that the cost is a factor.  Anyways, it is next Thursday; CT scan for planning and the solo radiation treatment.  I am not worried as I found radiation fairly "easy" 2 years ago.  I am worried about the CT scan of the chest and abdomen tomorrow, praying that it does not find more mets.  Thank you for your posts.  This forum has been the best help I've had.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2015 01:24AM hansaim wrote: Yay, kebab. So happy that you are here celebrating your birthday. I turn 45 in two months time. Here's to many more birthdays and making wonderful memories with your family.
Posts.Title: I turned 45 yesterday kebab Tina2

Posts.Content: May 30, 2015 01:58PM hansaim wrote: I am so sorry to hear about your progression. Chemo is so hard on your body. It is heart breaking and scary when you learn that it did not work. I have read on this board that some ladies failed a few chemos until they found the magic one. I pray that your next one is it. Hugs.
Posts.Title: Looking for some encouragement..chemo not working Sugarbaby5 starbrightlyshines

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2014 10:25PM hansaim wrote: My kids are 11 and almost 9.  It took me 3 months after my stage 4 diagnosis to tell them what was happening to me.  My daughter was in tears at school but my son became overly happy and loud kid for few days.  I told them that cancer was back and I have to take the chemo medicine.  But they do not know that it is terminal.  We bring up the subject once in a while, but we try to keep everything as normal as possible with their school, sports, music, etc. Stellar, I know what you mean by Mother's day.  In my son's grade 3 class this year, they did Mother's day tea.  All the moms came and watched the kids sing, dance, read poems.  It was lovely.  But I kept choking up thinking my son may be the only one without a mother at another Mother's day tea.  I am really hoping that this year was the last Mother's day tea his class hosts.
Posts.Title: Mothers with school aged children Kjones13 Kjones13

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2014 11:28AM hansaim wrote: I did radiation on T11 last summer. I had nausea, churning stomach, diarrhea for a couple of weeks. It was terrible but it did help with pain. Hang in there. Hugs.
Posts.Title: Radiation on Spine Iamstronger KiwiCatMom

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2014 08:09AM hansaim wrote: Hi, Stella.  I am sorry to hear that you are not doing well.  My bone mets progressed on Afinitor/exemestane last fall.  I knew the combo was not working as I could barely walk due to painful back and hips.  Last October, I needed a walker to get around.  I started Xeloda in November.  Within a couple of months, I graduated to a cane and now I am able to get around without any aids.  Pain also improved.  I take two Tylenols on a bad day these days, no narcotics.  I pray that X gets your cancer under control and help with pain. Living with cancer is indeed so difficult.  Even though I am feeling better this year, there is not a day that goes by without thinking about this disease and leaving my family behind.  Living in the moment is easier said than done.  Please do something to lift yourself up, maybe a treatment at a spa or something with your kids or just a good cry.  Hugs.

When mets progressed to the lungs last year for the first time, I did not have a clue. Two weeks can be a long time to wait for a scan. I hope you have pain meds to help you.
Posts.Title: For those who have experienced progression, did you feel it? terri-c leggo

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2014 08:44AM hansaim wrote: Hi, Laura.  I am so sorry that you are joining us here.  The initial few months are very difficult but it got better for me as the treatment went underway.  You are not alone.  There are many women who are doing well for a long time.  I hope your chemo is going well and SE is not too terrible.  Hugs.
Posts.Title: New to Stage IV Golfingirl hansaim

Posts.Content: hansaim wrote: My stage 4 dx was this July. I have bone mets; some on spine and extensive in pelvis. My first treatment as stage 4 was A/A. Before the three months scan, I knew that it was not working as the pain worsened and my mobility declined significantly while on A/A. Now I am on the 2nd cycle of Xeloda. I will be getting a scan after 4 cycles. In the mean time, I notice that the pain has improved and I am able to walk better. I can walk with a cane instead of a walker and can even take a few steps inside without a cane! Now here comes the question. When the pain and symptom improve, does it normally indicate stability or regression? Has anyone experienced a case where you felt better but had progression while on treatment? Thank you. Dx 3/2011, IDC, 3cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 1/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 7/14/2013, Stage IV Hormonal Therapy 1/8/2017 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 1/9/2017 Ibrance (palbociclib) Hormonal Therapy Faslodex (fulvestrant) Chemotherapy Abraxane (albumin-bound or nab-paclitaxel) Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy Halaven (eribulin) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: When pain improves hansaim formygirls

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 05:22AM hansaim wrote: I am so sorry.  I know what you mean about having to rely on a walker.  I had to use a walker to get around in and out of the house past fall because of progression in my pelvis and spine.  I am 43 years old!  But it gave me much needed support and stability and I was able to go out.  I found that the seat on the walker was really helpful, too.  I sat on it all the time, especially in the kitchen, while waiting for water to boil or whatever.  There are many choices.  You could rent one to see which one you like best.  You can also consult with an occupational therapist for a recommendation.  Hugs to you.
Posts.Title: More Fun in CancerLand! justjudie

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2015 08:37PM hansaim wrote: I am so sorry that you are here. I am in Vancouver, BC, so we are almost neighbours. For ER+ cancer, hormonal treatment can be very effective with much easier SEs than chemo. I go to the support group at the BC cancer agency and met a lady who has been on Arimidex for over 10 years and stable. She was dx'ed as stage 4 from the beginning. Do not lose hope. Many are doing well and there are lots of treatment options. Wish you the best outcome with your treatment.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with stage 4 with bone mets. Joyfuller EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2015 02:10AM hansaim wrote: Like many of you, it is leaving my family behind. My kids are now 10 & 12. Both are still in elementary school and getting them through high school seems like such a way off right now. I worry how my husband will manage when I am gone. For myself, I have grieved the loss of career, sexuality, healthy body, dreams, retirement, etc. But my loss seems to fade when I think of my children having to deal with a mom who is sick, bald, always on the couch, unable to volunteer at school. So sad that my children are growing up with "cancer" mom...

I hope that you come here to find information and support that you need. I stared at the blank space and cried every day for many weeks. Posts.Title: I'm in shock Maureen813

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2014 01:18AM hansaim wrote: I am so sorry that you are joining us.  The initial weeks and months after the stage 4 dx are emotionally draining and frightening.  Try to take one day at a time and live in the moment.  I know it is easier said than done.  After you start the treatment, you will feel better.  As for the questions, if you have symptoms/pain, ask for a referral to a symptom and pain management specialist.  For me, once the pain was controlled, everything seemed easier to manage.  Hugs.
Posts.Title: New to Stage IV...what to ask doctor? wrsmith2x mw900

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2014 10:45AM hansaim wrote: Hi, Patty.  It is heart breaking to having to tell the kids that the cancer has returned.  My children are 10 year old girl and 8 yr boy.  I told the teachers about it so they could keep an eye on the kids.  My daughter's teacher and friends kept me informed that she cried at school.  We would have a little chat after school and she was okay.  We attended a family program for children at the cancer hospital.  Therapists, nurses, counsellors spent an afternoon with us and 2 other families with similar aged kids, gave us a workbook with good information, answered questions from the kids.  It was helpful.  I hope you can find something like that.
Posts.Title: New to stage 4 - how do I help child PattyPeppermint graciesmom15

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2015 10:47PM hansaim wrote: I started Faslodex and Afinitor in November. The tumour marker has been a good indicator for me for the last 2.5 years. But this time, though the markers are going down, I am not feeling better. Back pain is worse and I am not as stable on my feet as I used to be so back on the cane I go. I had a spine MRI today. I am waiting for a PET scan to be scheduled. With the holidays, it may be in the new year. Thanks gals for waiting here with me.
Posts.Title: Having a scan? Waiting on results? The waiting room is open! exbrnxgrl gramen

Posts.Content: May 13, 2014 04:16PM hansaim wrote: Hi, listee.  I pray that your scan shows regression.  I know about waiting for scan results.  My onc at BC cancer is not very prompt about the results and is not good at sharing details, either.  Sometimes, I go to my GP for the scan results as she reads the reports with me.  If you have not done it already, go to the patient information and ask all reports to be copied to your family doctor.  Once the report is available, It is easier to book an appt with your GP rather than waiting to see your MO.  Good to hear from you.

Posts.Title: I'm Going to Disney World! Maybe You Can Too! TarheelMichelle Rosevalley

Posts.Content: May 31, 2015 08:38PM hansaim wrote: Torridon, I hear you!! I feel much the same way. Mets have changed everything I do. I have not bought new clothes, things for my home or garden for a long time. I trashed the dream house renovation plan. The ladies here are so right in that you do what you enjoy. But sometimes, especially after progression and change of treatment, nothing gives me joy. When I feel that way, I remind myself that I keep going because of my husband and two kids (12 and 9 yrs). Another week, another month, another year that I am around is more time that my kids have their mom. Yes, they will be fine after I die. My parents are close to my kids and my husband will do well for them, but they won't have mom. I want them to remember me and all that we did together. Hugs.
